medical material: Foreign objects intentionally placed in the body for therapeutic purposes (e.g., surgical clips, pacemakers, catheters, orthopedic hardware). Visible on imaging as artificial structures.
arterial wall calcification: Pathological deposition of calcium salts in arterial walls. Associated with atherosclerosis and increased cardiovascular risk.
cardiomegaly: Abnormal enlargement of the heart volume, commonly measured by cardiothoracic ratio >0.5 on chest X-ray. Causes include hypertension, valvular disease, and cardiomyopathy.
pericardial effusion: Abnormal fluid accumulation in the pericardial sac surrounding the heart. May cause cardiac tamponade if large.
coronary artery wall calcification: Calcium deposition in coronary arteries visualized on CT. Quantified by Agatston score for coronary artery disease risk assessment.
hiatal hernia: Protrusion of abdominal structures (typically stomach fundus) through the esophageal hiatus of the diaphragm into the thoracic cavity.
lymphadenopathy: Abnormal lymph node enlargement (>1cm short axis). Categorized as reactive, infectious, or malignant based on size, shape and distribution.
emphysema: Permanent destruction of alveolar walls and terminal airspace enlargement. Key component of COPD, characterized by decreased lung attenuation on CT.
atelectasis: Partial or complete collapse of lung tissue due to airway obstruction, compression, or surfactant deficiency. Causes reduced lung volume and air bronchogram absence.
lung nodule: Discrete pulmonary opacity â‰¤3cm in diameter. Requires monitoring for malignant features (spiculation, growth) versus benign causes.
lung opacity: Nonspecific term for any region of increased lung attenuation on imaging. Includes ground-glass opacity and consolidation patterns.
pulmonary fibrotic sequela: Post-inflammatory scarring with fibroblast proliferation causing irreversible architectural distortion and reticulation.
pleural effusion: Abnormal fluid accumulation in the pleural cavity. Classified as transudate or exudate based on Light's criteria.
mosaic attenuation pattern: Heterogeneous lung attenuation on CT with alternating regions of normal and decreased density. Indicates small airway disease or vascular pathology.
peribronchial thickening: Increased bronchial wall thickness (>1-2mm) due to inflammation, edema or fibrosis. Common in asthma and chronic bronchitis.
consolidation: Replacement of alveolar air by fluid, cells or tissue. Manifests as homogeneous lung opacification with air bronchograms.
bronchiectasis: Irreversible bronchial dilation with wall thickening. Classified as cylindrical, varicose or cystic. Causes chronic cough and recurrent infections.
interlobular septal thickening: Thickening of fibrous septa separating secondary pulmonary lobules. Appears as linear opacities perpendicular to pleura on CT.
